Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Cross-Sector Insights Toward Aligning Education Research and Real-World Impact

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This EAGER proposal is a partnership among the Joan Ganz Cooney Center, an independent R&D organization associated with the Sesame Workshop, E-Line media, a publisher of game-based learning products, and the Center for Games and Impact at Arizona State University. The goal of the project is to inform the development of an impact-based research methodology (IBR) to enable a more direct and overt connections between academic research on games and the development of educational products and services that are sustainable and scalable. Through consultation with other researchers and developers, the team is conducting series case studies to identify promising practices from three communities: 1) the tech-enabled services sector, particularly the idea of lean start up, 2) the social impact sector; and 3) the learning sciences and educational research sector.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this NSF grant was on advancing a set of key considerations for an impact-based research methodology, grounding these ideas in the context of our core focus, game-based-learning, but also stimulating an inclusive, cross-disciplinary dialogue that has greater likelihood in producing a generalizable methodology that gives rise to sustainable and scalable impact. Through these NSF EAGER funds, two-dozen individuals from multiple universities, from philanthropic organizations, from social impact communities, and from the tech-enabled service sectors came together for two days at Arizona State University. The goal of the meeting was to identify assumptions and advance methodologies and best practices for developing a tighter connection between promising research and real world scaled and sustainable impact. A shared assumption was to challenge overly simplistic, if not deterministic models, that treat designed product(s) as responsible for achieving outcomes on society-rather than with society.

We were able to synthesize discussions and findings into the development of a deeper understanding of the science and art of impact. Collectively, this work resulted in an initial methodology or set of lenses to consider when one is designing innovation for impact. It also resulted in an ecological model for characterizing innovation, one that is invitational and positions innovation not simply in the hands of the designers, but within the implementation itself in which the design, the impactee, the facilitators, and enabling ecosystem all come together to collectively realize impact goals. Key to this was a sense that the types of innovations we are building do not involve outcomes that lend themselves to technological fixes, instead requiring deep learning and active participation on the part of those responsible for realizing the core concepts associated with the innovation. Thus, leading to an ecological model of innovation for impact.

The important finding is the need for those involved in innovation design to move beyond what was designed, and instead to emphasize what people do with it and how the design enabled individuals to realize locally important goals. Consistent with views that treat technological products as tech-enabled services, this work went one step further and emphasized what the impactee is able to achieve as part of the innovation—focusing on the realization of meaningful impact goals. In this model, fidelity lives in the potential of the innovation to enable the impactee to realize goals that matter to them, with each implementation being another form of innovation. Focusing learning innovations on what people can do with it, requires that they the learner is deeply invested, is designing for possibilities not fully described by the innovation, and is critically reflecting on how to improve their effort. In this latter model, while technology might be a necessary component in an innovation profile, it is insufficient to enable the necessary conditions for the learner and system to thrive.

The latter requires that the learner, as one component of an implementation system, integrate core concepts-to-be-learned to realize personally-meaningful and locally-relevant goals. Central to this argument is the belief that when the technology, broadly conceived, takes responsibility for outcome obtainment, the intervention is unlikely to produce sustainable and scalable impact.
